children.name: a type of person or thing
kind
children.definition: a type of person or thing.Kindis less formal thantype, and is used especially in everyday English:
examples: The study is the first of its kind in Ireland.

children.name: all kinds/every kind
examples: He’s done all kinds of work.

children.name: the same kind
examples: I’d like to see you make the same kind of effort in practice that you make in the game.

children.name: a different kind
examples: Fossils of many different kinds have been found in this site.

children.name: the right/wrong kind
examples: It wasn’t the right kind of holiday for me.

children.name: the best/worst kind
examples: Not knowing what had happened to her was the worst kind of torture.

children.name: some kind
examples: Carved into the stone was some kind of design.

children.name: any kind
examples: There was no television, no radio – no technology of any kind.

children.name: various kinds
examples: The students had to read various kinds of academic materials.

children.name: a certain/particular kind
examples: A ‘besom’ is a particular kind of broom.

children.name: of its/their kind
examples: It is the biggest centre of its kind.

children.name: of this kind
examples: How can we be sure a disaster of this kind will not happen again?

children.name: of the worst/best etc kind
examples: This is hypocrisy of the worst kind.

children.name: what kind
children.definition: of something
examples: ?What kind of milk shake would you like?

children.name: that kind of thing
examples: He usually wears trainers and jeans, that kind of thing.

children.name: in a funny/strange etc kind of way
examples: In a funny kind of way, the bullying made me a stronger person.

children.name: precisely/exactly the kind
examples: This was precisely the kind of help that she needed.

children.name: kind of
examples: They sell all kinds of things.
The flowers attract several different kinds of insects.
Greg was working on some kind of deal in Italy.
Get me a sandwich – any kind will do.

children.name: of this/that kind etc
examples: Accidents of this kind are extremely common.

children.name: of various/many/different kinds etc
examples: They export farming machinery and tools of various kinds.

children.name: style
children.definition: a particular design or fashion for sth such as clothes, hair, furniture etc: mẫu, kiểu, phong cách
examples: The new library is a blend of various architectural styles.
Car styles have changed radically in the past 20 years.
traditional/modern style
The rooms are furnished in a modern style.
style of
a completely new style of painting
style[adj/adv]
western-style/Japanese style etc
The room was simply furnished, Japanese-style.

children.name: category
children.definition: a group of people or things that are all of the same type – used when there is a clear system for deciding which group something belongs to: danh mục, hạng mục
examples: She won the best actress category at the Oscars.

children.name: belong to a category
examples: A lot of water plants belong to this category.

children.name: fall/come into a category
examples: The data we collected fell into two categories.

children.name: fit into a category
examples: Rogers doesn’t fit into either category.

children.name: put somebody/something into categories
examples: People are individuals and you can’t really put them into categories.

children.name: group somebody/something into categories
examples: Let’s start by grouping the books into categories.

children.name: divide/split something into categories
examples: The exhibition of 360 paintings is divided into three categories.

children.name: a broad/general category
examples: Our range of programmes come into three broad categories.

children.name: the main category
examples: This is the main category of patients.|There are two main categories of university fees.

children.name: a major categorya major category of vehicle|
examples: Theft is one of the major categories of crime.

children.name: a special category
children.definition: one that nothing else belongs to
examples: The constitution was defined as a special category of law.

children.name: a distinct/separate category
children.definition: clearly different from others
examples: Animals fall into distinct categories.

children.name: category of
examples: The three major categories of rock are: igneous, metamorphic, and sedimentary.
There are five categories of workers.

children.name: people in the over-45age category
examples: Seats are available in eight of the tenprice categories.

children.name: like this
children.definition: /like that especiallyspokenof the type that you have just been talking about:
examples: The children need new pens and pencils and things like that.
People like that really annoy me.
I’m not sure what to do. I’ve never been in a situation like this before.

children.name: class U
children.definition: class  a number of people or things that are considered as being of the same group because they have the same physical features, qualities etc:

children.name: class of
examples: ▪ French is one of a class of languages known as the Romance languages.
▪ Doctors are reluctant to prescribe a new class of drugs, especially ones which need to be taken for long periods of time.

children.name: variety
children.definition: a type that is slightly different from others in the same group: loại

children.name: variety of
examples: This is a new variety of apple.
The French make many varieties of cheese, from both cows’ and goats’ milk.
At that time, all newsreaders spoke a variety of English spoken in southern England, known as Received Pronunciation.

children.name: genre
children.definition: a type of art, music, literature etc. that has a particular style or feature: thể loại
examples: Science fiction as a genre is relatively new.
Italian filmmakers made their own versions of the classic Hollywood genres - the western, the gangster film, the musical.
He has written novels in several genres, most notably science fiction.

children.name: form
children.definition: one type of sth from all the ones that are possible – used especially when things have different physical characteristics, or in certain fixed phrases: dạng
examples: The first primitivelife formsconsumed various materials, including hydrogen sulfide, and released oxygen.
theartforms of the twentieth century.

children.name: form of
examples: The bicycle is an environment-friendly form of transport.
There are many forms of heart disease.
Melanoma is a form of skin cancer.
In those days, horses were the commonestform of transport.
We need to use alternativeforms of energy.

children.name: nature
children.definition: used when talking about a particular type of thing:
examples: of a ... nature:
Many people find it embarrassing to discuss problems of a sexual nature.
of a political/historical/technical/scientific/sexual nature
The support being given is primarily of a practical nature.
books of an erotic nature
of a different/similar nature
On the plains the farmers have to deal with frequent floods, but up in the hills their problems are of a different nature.
of this/that nature
Minor incidents of this nature normally occur about once a month.
Children at this age commonly refer to being eaten up by tigers and lions and things of that nature.
be in the nature of sthto be like something
The cruise was to be in the nature of a ‘rest cure’.

children.name: ilk
children.definition: of that/his/their etc  of that type, his type etc - use this especially about types that you do not like or respect:
examples: Environmentalists, feminists, and others of that ilk regularly try to drive shows like this off the air.
Desserts ($5) were of the tiramisu, crème brûlée, chocolate torte ilk.

children.name: type
children.definition: one member of a group of people or things that have similar features or qualities.Typeis the usual word to use in scientific or technical contexts. In everyday English, people usually usekindorsort:

children.name: this/that type
examples: He is not suited to this type of work.

children.name: a particular type
examples: Have you flown this particular type of aircraft before?

children.name: the same type
examples: The use the same type of axe as a tool and a weapon.

children.name: a different type
examples: I’ve learned to work with different types of people.

children.name: a new type
examples: These architects felt the time had come for a new type of public building.

children.name: the main type
examples: Methane is the main type of gas produced.

children.name: skin/hair type
examples: The best cleanser for you depends on your skin type.

children.name: blood typeAmerican English
children.definition: one of the classes into which human blood can be separated
examples: Mother and child had the same blood type.

children.name: personality type
children.definition: with a particular type of character
examples: Find out your personality type by answering our simple questionnaire.

children.name: soil type
children.definition: for example, sandy soil or clay soil
examples: The plant thrives in a wide range of soil types.
In informal speech, people sometimes usethese/those type ofbefore a plural noun, but do not use this in writing.

children.name: type of
examples: What type of music do you like?
There are two main types of sleep.
of this/that/each etc typeI’ve already seen a few movies of this type.
of various/many/different types etcThey export farming machinery and tools of various types.
Grammar Type,kind, andsortare countable nouns, and they should be plural after plural determiners :
Many sorts of jobs (NOT Many sort of jobs) require computing skills.
Use a singular or uncountable noun with no determiner aftertype/kind/sort of:

children.name: children who attend the same type of school
examples: This sort of behaviour is totally unacceptable.
Use a singular, plural, or uncountable noun with no determiner aftertypes/kinds/sorts of:
How common are these types of illness OR illnesses?

children.name: sort
children.usage: [Sort is less formal than type, and is used especially in everyday British English]
children.definition: a type of person or thing.

children.name: this/that sort
examples: We must ensure that this sort of thing does not happen again.

children.name: some sort
examples: There has been some sort of error.

children.name: the same sort
examples: We had the same sort of background.

children.name: a similar sort
examples: It’s a similar sort of house.

children.name: a different sort
examples: Barbara never stopped wanting a different sort of life.

children.name: the right sort
examples: Wearing the right sort of clothing could save your life.

children.name: other sorts
examples: What other sorts of books do you like?

children.name: all sorts
children.definition: many different sorts
examples: He collects all sorts of musical instruments.

children.name: of one sort or another
children.definition: of various different sorts
examples: Quite a large number of them suffered injuries of one sort or another.

children.name: sort of
examples: What sort of shampoo do you use?

children.name: all sorts (of something)(= a lot of different types of things )
examples: I like all sorts of food – I’m not fussy.

children.name: of this/that sort
examples: On expeditions of this sort, you have to be prepared for trouble.

children.name: of various/many/different sorts etc
examples: They export farming machinery and tools of various sorts.

children.name: of some sort/some sort of sth(= used when you do not know exactly what type )
examples: He wondered if Rosa was in some sort of trouble.
There was a game of some sort going on inside.
Most of the victims developed psychological problemsof one sort or another(= of various different types ).
They do burgers, pizzas,that sort of thing.

children.name: update
children.definition: a new form of something which existed at an earlier time
examples: It's an updateofan old 60's movie.

children.name: version
children.definition: 1a copy of something that has been changed so that it is slightly different
examples: version of
a new version of the software
new/modern/final etc version
theoriginal versionof the text
English/German/electronic/film etc version(= presented in a different language or form )
a Japanese version of an English play
I think I preferred the television version.
the human version of mad cow disease
2someone’s version of an event is their description of it, when this is different from the description given by another person
version of
according to the officialversion of events
Could Donna’s version of what happened that night be correct?
3 the ... version of somethinga way of explaining or doing something that is typical of a particular group or period of time
the ... version of something of
the Marxist version of economics
Is the coffee break the adult version of recess?
a later versiona later version of the software
an updated versionan updated version of the 'Best Pub' guide

children.name: a new version
examples: There has been an outcry over a new version of the world’s most popular ballet.

children.name: a different version
examples: The two groups listened to different versions of the story.

children.name: the latest version
examples: The company will soon release the latest version of its network operating system.

children.name: the original/first version
examples: The original version was in Latin but later editions were in English.

children.name: the final version
examples: The final version of the report omitted these criticisms.

children.name: an earlier version
examples: The President vetoed an earlier version of the bill.

children.name: the film version
children.definition: a film of a book or play
examples: He appeared in the film version of 'Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince'.

children.name: a revised version
examples: In a revised version of the script, this scene was cut .

children.name: a modified version
children.definition: one that has some small changes
examples: The article is a modified version of a paper that first appeared in an academic journal.

children.name: a simplified version
examples: This simplified version of Shakespeare’s play is intended for younger children.

children.name: an improved version
examples: The manufacturers come up with new, improved versions each year.

children.name: an abridged version
children.definition: one that is shortened from the original but not changed in any other way
examples: Reader’s Digest published abridged versions of many popular novels.

children.name: the unabridged version
children.definition: not shortened – used when this version is long
examples: the unabridged version of 'Moby Dick'

children.name: the uncut version
children.definition: used about a film that includes parts that were not in the film when it was shown in cinemas
examples: the uncut version of 'Bladerunner'

children.name: classification
children.definition: a group that something is divided into
examples: There are five job classifications.

children.name: be sb's type
children.definition: besb'stype

children.name: to be the type of person that someone thinks is attractive
examples: _He's a nice enough guy - he's just not my type.
_I'd have thought Ben was more your type.
